conversation.content: You have really beautiful eyes, you know that?
[cry loudly] Nobody's said that to me in years. Most people just see the body, the performance, never actually look at my face.
I'm sorry, I didn't mean to upset you.
No no, these are good tears. You'd be surprised how rare genuine compliments are in my line of work. Everything's usually about measurements and moves.
How long have you been dancing?
Seven years this December. Started right after my daughter was born, needed the money fast and it was the only job that paid enough for childcare and rent.
You have a daughter?
Mia, she's seven now. Smart as hell, already reading at a fourth grade level. Her teachers say she's gifted but I already knew that.
[anxious] Does she know what you do?
She thinks I'm a night shift nurse. The hours match up and it explains why I sleep during the day. I'll tell her the truth when she's older, when she can understand nuance.
That must be hard, keeping that secret.
[long pause] The hardest part is missing bedtime stories. I record myself reading her favorite books so she can listen when I'm at work. She says my voice helps her sleep better than anything.
You're a good mom.
[laugh loudly] A good mom who takes her clothes off for money? That's a new one. Most people think those two things can't coexist in the same person.
I think you're doing what you have to do.
[very sincerely] You're different from the usual crowd. Most guys either pity me or fetishize me, but you're just talking to me like I'm a regular person.
You are a regular person.
[confidently] I make more than most corporate managers, actually. Put away fifteen thousand just this year for Mia's college fund. This job won't last forever but her education will.
Can I buy you a real drink? Not a work drink?
My shift ends at two. There's a 24-hour diner three blocks down that makes incredible pancakes. Meet me there if you're serious about seeing who I actually am.
